div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: Old Scotch Whiskey
div.p: THE GREATEST care should be taken in what we eat and drink, yet we are too often in-different and careless, notwithstanding health depends on what we eat and drink.

In regard to drink nothing but the best should be taken. It costs no more than the indifferent quality, if people would only ask for what they know is best Old Scotch Whiskey is the most wholesome beverage yet known Mackie's Scotch Whiskey gives an undoubted guarentee to those who are not judges of quality.
CITY ANALYST'S LABORATORY, 138 BATH STREET, GLASGOW, 8TH October, 1906.

I hereby certify that I have taken samples of every vatting of Mackle's White Horse Cellar Blend of Scotch Whiskey used in bottling during the month of September, and the results of my analyses indicate that it conforms to the standard for Pot Still Scotch Whiskey set up in the London case. I am also of opinion that it is an old Whisky of excellent quality and flavour, which has been well matured in wood.
JOHN CLARK, Ph.D., F.C.S.,F.I.C., Public Analyst for the City of Glasgow and the Counties of Lanark Renfrew, &c.
N.B.-This Whisky is the same as supplied to the Red Cross Society, London, to the House of Lords and House of Commons.

div.head: Administration des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat Egyptien
div.p: AVIS

L'Administation des Chemins de der de l'Etat a l'honneur de porter a la connaissance du public qu'il sera procede, la Samedi deux Mars prochain, a neuf heures du matin a la vente aux encheres publiques, suivant Kaimet-Mazid, aux Magasins Generaux de Boulac, (Caire), d'une quantite de 100,000 vieilles traverses en hois qui se trouvent sur la ligne de Zagaz g-Neifiche ou on peut les examiner. Les conditions de vente penvent etre consultees au Bureau Central des Magasins de Boulac, chaque jour de neuf heures du matin a une heure p.m., les Dimanches et jours feries exceptes.

Pour etre admis a concourir, le soumissionnaire dera verser au prealable, une somme de L.E. 50 a titre de depot provisoire. Le soumissionnaire declare adjudicataire devra parfaire cette somme jusqu'a concurrence du 10% du montant de l'offre agreee et enlever a sesfrais les lots qui lui seront adjuges dans undelai de trois mois a compter de la date de l'avis de l'acceptation de son offre.
Les offres devront etre accompagnees d'une feuille de papier timbre de 30 milliemes. Elles seront adressees par la poste sous pli recommande a:
"Monsieur le Chef de Service des Madasins, Chemins de Fer de l'Etat, Boulac, Caire.
et sous double enveloppe, l'interieure portant la suscription suivante:
Offre pour achat de vieilles traverses". Toute offre faite ou deposee posterierement au jour et a l'heure ei-dessus designes me sera pas prise en consideration.
L'Administration ne s'engage pas a accepter les prix les plus eleves ni a donner suite aux soumissions presente; elle se reserve le droit de diviser la vinte.

div.head: SANITATION IN EGYPT.
div.p: Mr. J.M. Robertson, M.P., whose recent visit to Egypt excited such interest, has already begun to write about this country, and the first contribution that we have noticed from his pen is a letter published in the "Laneet," of the 26th ulto, on the subject of sanitation in Egypt in reference to a contribution on the the same subject from the Cairo correspondent of that paper. Mr. Robertson's letter runs as follows :

What strikes a visitor interested in these matters is that the drainage of Cairo is only one item in the great problem of Egyptian sanitation. Your correspondent appears to imply that while there is a terribly high infantile mortality in Cairo, the health conditions in-the villages are relatively good. It is I to be feared that this is not the case. By all accounts the infantile mortality is everywhere enormous ; one authority has repeatedly put it at two of every three children born. Certainly the conditions of water-supply and sewage in the villages are shockingly bad. Everywhere the drinking water is obviously polluted in every conceivable way. Even in the small modern town of Helouan, a Cairo health resort on the edge of the desert, I have seen a pestiferous open channel, fortuitously formed, slowly carrying and depositing filth in one of the side areas. The water supply of Helouan appears to be from wells, and in the porous desert soil percolation seems inevitable.

div.head: P & O WEEKLY MAIL and PASSENGER SERVICES P & O

G. ROYLE .. ... PORT SAID,
HASELDEN & Co. ... .. ... ...ALEXANDRIA.
or from the Company's superintendent in Egypt,
F. G. DAVIDSON, Suez.

As to Cairo, it is to be noted that while the Anglo Indian expert is preparing his report a number of streets are being laid with asphalte. This is in itself a desirable reform, but as the asphalte would have to be broken up again in case of a system of drainage being set up, it is to be presumed that the Government do not contemplate such a system, but have in view an extension or reform of the present method of removal by sanitary carts. If that be so, the time has clearly come for the development of such a system in the other towns and villages likewise. Your readers may remember that during the South African war Sir Arthur Conan Doyle made it a part of the case against the Boers that, in their towns they had no drains. The British people should make the effort to realise that that is the state of things not only throughout the British Colonies in South Africa—where it is justifiable—but throughout all Egypt (barring Alexandria) under British control. And even the Alexandria sewage system is very defective. The report of the Public Health Department for 1905 expressly ascribes the persistence of plague in Alexandria partly to the dilapidated state of the drains.

Concerning the cesspools of Cairo, it may be true that some of the latest aro well built ; but the official reason given in the past for discontinuing the system of drainage begun before the occupation was that digging operations in Cairo were so often fatal to the diggers by reason of the infiltration of sewage from the existing cesspools. There is, I understand, no regular inspection of cesspools, no enforced law for their being periodically emptied, no limitation as to their size, and no requirements as to their being cemented.

It is to be feared that the explanation given by your correspondent of the long delay in filling up the open ditch in Cairo called the Khalig—to the effect that the resistance came from Moslem fanaticism—is unduly favourable to the Government. The real reason seems to have been the official unwillingness to spend money on public health. What was finally done was to give the ditch, as a concession to a tramway company on condition of their filling it up. They did so, and laid a double tramway line on the narrow roadway they made, thus constituting the most dangerous thoroughfare in Cairo.

As to the present Cairo water-supply, on which your correspondent passes no judgment, I may mention that in the School of Police the drinking water is very carefully filtered, and the authorities are satisfied that this precaution has greatly raised the health standard. That is to say, the ordinary water is officially recognised to be bad. It is always discoloured at high Nile. Your readers can infer what are the chances for the rest of Cairo, with its population of nearly three quarters of a million, and for the rest of Egypt, where the water supply is still primeval, being generally taken from the Nile, or unprotected wells and canals, or stagnant pools.

Let me add that in Cairo there are only some five or six public latrines, that these are solely for men, and all in a small space in or near the Esbekieh Gardens, that they emit even in winter a great stench (one lately blew up from the gases gonerated beneath it) ; that natives can be seen in open day availing themselves (for all purposes) of the paths and walls in some of the principal tramway thoroughfares ; that there are only some three or four drinking fountains, set up by pious Moslem donors ; and even in some modern streets may be seen pails or jars of unfiltered and sometimes dirty drinking water, charitably placed for the poor by Muslem householders. These jars commonly stand under the trees where filth accumulates. There are no public washhouses, nor public baths, apart from the impossible baths attached to the M square and this in a country where for six months of the year the climate is tropical. Yet another item Flat tenements of five or oven six storeys are now being rushed up, though many complaints are made in the newspapers that the pressure is often hardly enough to take the water to the second floors. I say nothing as to the inspection of milk supply which, I fear, is much needed.

div.head: Zetland Lodge.
div.p: The installation banquet of the Zetland Lodge will be held at the New Khedivial Hotel at Alexandria this evening. Covers will be laid for sixty persons.

div.head: Cairo Syndicate, Ltd.
div.p: The Committee of the London Stock Exchange has fixed to-morrow as a special settling day in Cairo Syndicate, Limited — 5,000 Vendors Shares of £1 eaoh fully paid, Nos. 8 to 5,007.

div.head: Band Performance.
div.p: By kind permission of Lieut. Col. Macfarlane, D.S.O., and officers, the band of the King' Own Soottish Borderers will play on the terrace of the National Hotel from 4 to 6 p.m. to-morrow.

div.head: Roumanian Steamship Service.
div.p: Notwithdtandibg a thick fog, which prevented a number of vessels entering the port of Alexandria yesterday, the S.S. Romania, of ths Roumanian Maritime Service, came in at sohednle time with 45 first-class passengers.

div.head: Parcel Poet
div.p: A postal notice states that with effect from the 1st March next all parcels not withdrawn from the Post Office within three days atter their arrival will subject to a demurrage due of 5 milliemes per day per parcel exclusive of the day of arrival and withdrawal.

div.head: Fire at Port Said.
div.p: At Port Said, on Saturday morning, towards 8 o'clock, eight dwellings in the Arab quarter were destroyed by a fire which had been caused by the explosion of a lamp. Fanned by a N.W wind, the fire threatened to assume considerable proportions, but the fire brigade Boon hemmed it in.

div.head: Masked Balls.
div.p: A grand masked ball will be given at the Alhambra to-night on the occasion of Shrove Tuesday, beginning at midnight. Prizes will be given to the prettiest, most elegant, and most comical costumes. The theatre will be appropriately decorated and illuminated. Another ball will be given at the Tour Eiffel music hall.

div.head: Coptie Now Testament.
div.p: Dr. L. Delaporte is publishing two important works opon the Coptie New Testament, under the auspices of the Libraire Paul Genthner, 68 Rue Mazarine, Paris. The price to subscribers is only 4 francs each if applied for early, but only 100 copies of each will be printed. These books are "Fragments Sahidiques du Nouvean Testament, Les Epitres Catholiques" and "Fragments Sahidiques du Nouveau Testament. Apocalypse."

div.head: Sand from Syria.
div.p: Peculiarly disagreeable weather came over Alexandria yesterday afternoon. The atmosphere assumed a very dull yellow character similar to that of a bad khamseen, and a north wind blew the sand about so that walking was very unpleasant. It is presumed that the sand, which filled, the air, has been blown by the strong north-westerly wind from the Syrian deserts.

div.head: Bank of Egypt
div.p: The net profit of the Bank of Egypt for the past year, after providing for bad and doubtful debts,etc., and inclnding £14,655 brought down, was £151,405. The directors have transferred £40,000 to reserve, and now recommend a dividend of 6 percent for the half-year, free of inoome-tax, making 10 percent for the year, also a bonus of 8 per cent (20s. per share), leaving a balanoe of £ 15,357 to be carried forward.

div.head: In Aid of Russian Refugees.
div.p: The committee formed in 1905 in aid of Russian refugees met on Saturday evening at the residence of M. A. Cattaui to examine and close the accounts of the subscription fund. Of a total of £1,600, £1,000 bad been sent to the central committee in London; through the British Consulate in Cairo. The remaining balanoe of £600, having been subsoribed subsequently, will be distributed among the Russians in Cairo.

div.head: New Quay Estate.
div.p: There was a poor attendance and no animation at yesterday's auction of Blocks X, XXI, and XXIII of the new quay estate. The sale wa» advertised to commence at 4 p.m., but as there was such a poor attendance bidding did not begin until 4.30 o'clock. A commencement was made with Blook X, but none of the four lots of this blook evoked a single bid. Block XXI was withdrawn owing to a difficulty with the Government. Block XXIII was sold, with the exception of Lots 1 and 2, to the Windsor Hotel Company.

div.head: Suicide in Hospital.
div.p: The Egyptian Hospital of Port Said was on Friday the scene of a ghastly suicide. A young Frenchman, Philippe Dujean, who bad been landed from the Messageriee S.S.Ernest Simons, by order of the ship's dootor, was admitted to the hospital, suffering from seute neurasthenia. There was nothing in the afternoon to show that he had any intention of taking his life, and so the nurse had left him alone abont 4 o'clock. Dujean ate heartily, and then, unnoticed, he took a table-knife with him and locked himself up in the bathroom. Here be remained for half an hour before his absence was noticed, and his body was found in a pool of blood, streaming from ghastly wounds in the throat and stomaoh.

div.head: THE NEW FLOTATIONS.
div.p: WINDSOR HOTELS COMPANY LTD.

We understand that a company is about to be formed to take over the present Windsor Hotel at Alexandria, and the flotation will take place shortly. The company will be English, and the capital will be £120,000 in £118,750 ordinary shares of £1 and 25,C0O deferred shares of one shilling each. Only a portion of the capital (£80,000) will be offered to the pnblic, the balance having been taken firm by the parties interested, who are well known residents in Cairo and Alexandria. Yesterday a magnificent site was purchased by the directors on the quay front at the auction held by the Alexandria Municipality, on which it is proposed to build a new hotel. It is 6,819 square pios in area and the purchase price was abont P.T. 1,000 per pio. The lot in question is marked No. 23 and the different parcels bought are Nos. 2,3, 5 and 6. The site is joBt opposite the old Santi Restaurant. It is expected that the flotation will take place about the end of next month. We may mention that the land purchased yesterday is to be handed over to the company at cost price. No cash underwriting commissions are to be paid for in connection with the flotation. The allotment is to be made as far as possible pro rata. Five founders' shares will be given for every hundred ordinary shares allotted.
ANOTHER BANK FOR EGYPT.

The Bauque d'Ecompte et de Reports d'Egypte et de Soudan was registered January 29, with a capital of £500,625 in 125,000 ordinary shares of £4 each and 12,500 founders' shares of 1s. each, to carry on the business of a banking, discount, and financial undertaking, with head office in London, and such branches in Egypt or elsewhere as may he deemed expedient. Five per oent of the available profits is to be applied to reserve fund, after which a dividend up to 6 per cent. is to be paid on the ordinary shares. Ten per cent. of any residue is to be paid to the directors by way of additional remuneration, 80 per oent. of what remains is to be divided among the ordinary shareholders, and 40 per cent. thereof among the founders' shareholders take 60 per cent. and founders' shares 40 per cent. of any surplus assets. div.head: GHEZIREH MANSIONS, LIMITED.
div.p: The Ghezireh Mansions, Limited, is another English company. Its capital is £200,0D0 in 200,000 shares of £1 each with power to increase to £400,000 upon resolution of the Board. This company has been formed to carry on business in Egypt, the Sudan and Cyprus, and more particularly to at once acquire certain freehold land situate at Ghezireh, near Cairo. The directors have secured a plot of land of about 10,000 square metres forming part of the estate of the Ghezireh Palace Hotel, and known as the Harem Buildings, situated at the immediate approach to the new Boulac Bridge at Ghezireh and having a large frontage on the new tramway route which will lead direct to the Pyramids.

The issue consists of 99,993 ordinary shares at par of which 30,000 fully paid up shares at par are taken by the vendors as part consideration of the purchase price. The directors and their friends have applied for 21,250 shares, which will be allotted to them or their nominees at par,leaving for public issue 48,748 ordinary shares of £1 each, payable 3s. per share upon application and 7s. per share upon allotment, and the balance in two calls of 5s. each payable on the 20th March and the 20th April, 1907. There are no preference or founder's shares. Share warrants to bearer will be issued when required. The directors are Dr. Axel Thierry Preyer (proprietor). Cairo, chairman ; Louis Pitelle (managing director. Usine a Gaz et Central Electrique du Caire), Cairo; Pierre Savoyen (ex-director Contenieux, Credit Foncier Egyptien), Cairo ; Moba med Mahwoud Bey Khalil advocate), Cairo ; Alexander Henry Skynder (architect). Cairo.

div.head: OMNIUM FINANCIAL CO.
div.p: It is stated that Rostovizs Bey, who was to have been chairmen of the board of directors of the Omnium Financial Company,has retired. The Omnium Financial Company is to be a tranaformation of Messrs. Paten and Wenger's business into a limited liability company.

div.head: STOCKBROKERS' COMPANY.
div.p: Among the local stockbroking firms who are turning themselves into companies are, it is reported, the firm of Munci, Levy and Co., of Cairo, with a capital of £50,000, and also the firm of Negim.

div.head: FANATICAL OUTBREAK.
div.p: OUTRAGES AT BEYROUT.
Grave troubles are reported from Beyrout, where on the last day of Kourban-Beyram a number of Moslems committed an absolutely unprovoked attack on Christians, killing four and wounding seven.

The following is the version of the affray that reaches us from well-informed sources. On the above mentioned holiday a large number of Beyrout Moslems made an excursion to Dbaye, near the water-works by the Beyrout-Mamiltein line, and after passing some convivial hours in picturesque scenery, testified their appreciation of their snrronndings by letting off their revolvers. A gendarme or soldier of the Lebanon Militia protested politely against this dangerous feu de joie, whereupon the Moslems, inflamed by "araki" and fauaticism, called him a Christian dog, beat and stripped him, and carried off his rifle to the railway station. There they boarded the Beyrout train, and fearing action on the part of the Lebanese police at the stations of Dora, Nahr Antelias, etc., which are within the Lebanon district, clapped their pistols to the heads of the railway officials and ordered them to take the train through to a point some 400 yards short of the Beyrout Medawar station, informing them they wonld be shot should they attempt to stop at any of the intermediate stations. The officials protested, but in such a case the unarmed man must perforce give way to an aggravated application of the "argumentum baculinum." Away went the train and little more would have been heard of the incident had not the half savage passengers taken it into their heads to open fire from the carriages at passing Christians. By the time the train reached their destination, a point some 500 yards from Medawar station, they had accounted for eleven persons, four of whom have since died of their wounds.

The Foreign Consuls naturally enough protested against this outrageous conduct to the Vali of Beyrout, but though "measures have been taken to secure the arrest of the malefactors" no one has yet been arrested, so far as we are aware, and several of the persons concerned in this scandalous affray are said to have arrived at Port Said. We hope that they will not have occasion to stay in Egypt for—though we are by no means prone to xenophobia—there are certain varieties of "intrus" to whom we have the strongest objection.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive left Siwa Oasis yesterday on his return to Marsa Matrouh. His Highness is expected to arrive in Cairo on the 20th inst.

div.head: EGYPTIAN ARMY.
div.p: Lieutenant E.S. Girdwood, the Cameronians (Soottish Rifles),has been taken on the strength of the Egyptian Army with ths rank of Bimbashi, and is posted to the 11th Sudanese.
Lieutenant P. C. Joyce, the Connaught Rangere, has also been taken on the strength of the Egyptian Army, with the rank of Bimbashi.

div.head: FUNERAL OF MR. SPAGNOLO.
div.p: The funeral of the late Mr. Alexander Spagnolo, Spanish Consul and Acting Spanish Diplomatic Agent, took place this morning. The train conveying the mortal remains of the deceased arrived at Alexandria from Cairo at 10 o'olook, and was met on arrival by the members of the Diplomatic and Consular Corps and a large gathering of friends and acquaintances. The pall-bearers were M. Escoffier. Judge Vazqoez M. Alexander Sursock, and M. Achilles Lunghis. The cortege proceeded to the Latin Cemetery, where the interment took place.
Mme Spagnolo and her ohildren sincerely thank all their friends and acquaintances who have testified to their sympathy in their cruel bereavement.

div.head: UNITED EGYPTIAN LANDS.
div.p: We are authorised by the management ot the United Egyptian Lands, Limited, to state that plot 1 on the company's Rodah Island Estate, having an area of 2,600 metres, has been sold to Mr. Neghib Sursock at the rate of L.E. 7 per metre. An option has been given to the same gentleman, representing a group of capitalists in Alexandria, for plots 2, 3, 4, 17, and 18, with a total area of 12,187 metres, at the average price of L.E. 8 per metre. The plans referring to these plots will be in the hands of the public in two days' time.

div.head: FRENCH SCHOOLS IN THE EAST.
div.p: M Chariot's mission to the East has evidently given dissatisfaction to the Quai d'Orsay, for we understand that the French Government is sending out to Egypt M. Colin, who will study the French educational system here.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The S.S. Sailor Prince, with passengers and general cargo, left Malta on the 9th inst., and is due at Alexandria on Wednesday.
The S.S. Asiatic Prince, with passengers and general cargo, left London on the 10th inst, and is due at Alexandria on or about the 27th.

div.head: SUCCESSFUL ANIMAL SHOW.
div.p: The annual Animal Show was held at Nicosia a under the auspices of the Committee for the Improvement of Cyprus Stock on the 28th inst. Fortunately the weather was milder than it had been during the previous week, and stockowners were not deterred by clmatic conditions from sending in their animals, as was feared might be the case, and a good number of entries was recorded. Ths donkey class appeared to be exceptionally strong, both numerically and in point of quality; the size and general build of these Island-bred animals being remarkably good. It is something of a revelation to strangers to see what big staunch, shapely donkeys Cyprus can produce, and it is to be hoped that great care will continue to be exercised by the committee and by Cypriot donkey breeders in maintaining the standard already attained. For several years a fair number of these animals has been regularly exported to India for account of the Indian Government, and now an increasing supply is being shipped annually to Egypt at prices which cannot be other than remunerative.

Donkey breeding in this Island therefore seems to be an industry to befostered, although from the following tables, showing the total annual exports of horses, donkeys, and mules, it will be seen that the numbers sent away from the Island vary considerably from year to year:-

Having regard to the foreign demand, it would seem very desirable that regulations should be published and made known to local breeders respecting the eligibility of animals for registration in the stud book, so that defiuite strains may be created, pedigrees accurately recorded, and stock-owners may be taught to see the advantage from a commercial point of view of breeding their arimals true to type.

The classes for horses were not on so even a level, and judging by the somewhat heterogeneous collection paraded, it would seem at if the native breeders either do not know or have not adopted the ideal type of native pony which, presumably, the Committee take at their standard.

On Saturday, 26th instant, the Annual Zuptieh sports were held at Nicosia and a considerable number of spectators gathered together for this popular fixture. Rather more elaborate arrangements than usual had been made, and a few novel events were introduced into the programme.
A considerable quantity of Syrian wheat has just been imported. The importation of cereals into such an eminently corn growing land as Cyprus, on anything like a large scale, is a doubtful blessing.
Eight degrees and nine degrees of frost were registered on two nights last week in Nicosia. This beats the reoord for many years.

div.head: BREAKDOWN OF MESSAGERIES STEAMER.
div.p: The Messageries Maritimes mail steamer Natal, which was overdue at Suez, had a breakdown in her machinery in the Red Sea, and arrived this morning in tow of the company's steamer Aunam.
Steamers arriving yesterday from the Red Sea experienced difficulties in the Golf of Suez owing to the dense fog, which is still prevailing at Suez, but it is apparently clearing up today.

div.head: THE SINAI FRONTIER.
div.p: The result of the recent frontier dispute between Egypt and Turkey has considerably increased our topographical knowledge of that part of the Sinaitic Peninsula. The Survey Department are now publishing the following maps of that district:

div.p: Among other changes made by the Italian Foreign Office are the following:-
M. Gulio Pestalozze, Colonial Agent at Aden, has been promoted Consul General to Tripoli.
M. Pellegrini, Vice Consul at Port Said, has been transferred to B zerta.

div.head: NEW THEATRE FOR ALEXANDRIA
div.p: The Egyptian Estates, Limited, have given M. Conegliano. lessee of the Alhambra Theatre, notice to quit the theatre at the end of May, and that theatre, which has been established for ten years past, will soon be demolished. M. Conegliano has chosen a magnificent site for a new theatre close to the old terminus of the Ram'eh Railway on the Casulli property. He has taken it on long lease and already the work of construction has made considerable progress. The theatre is being built of stone and iron and will be of very solid constrnotion. It will accommodate about two thousand persons, while the garden in which it will be situated will be large enough to contain some thousands more.

The stage of the new theatre will be much larger than that of the Zizinia. There will be two rows of boxes and a large amphitheatre and gallery. The regulations laid down by the Alexandria Municipality are being scrupulously followed in order to assure the safety of the spectators.

The gardens will be a special feature of this place of entertainment. Being close to the sea, they will form a delighfully cool retreat in the summer evenings. The theatre, which is to be called the New Alhambra Theatre, will be ready at the beginning of next May, for the work of construction is being carried on night and day. The theatre will be opened with a serial of Italian operas and operettas.

div.head: PLOTTERS IN CAIRO.
div.p: Many are the obscure little presses hidden away in small priming establishments in Cairo and Alexandria, which have been busy of late printing Young Turkish leaflets. These are despatched in masses to Constantinople from Alexandria, and but few evade the vigilance of the police and postal officials of the Padishah. All these are directed against the alleged plot to pass over the Heir-Apparent and to place on the Throne in sucession to Abdul Hamid his third and favourite son, Prince Burhaned-din, who, according to Ottoman law only comes 14 h in the order ofsuceession to the Sultanate. The people of Turkey are warned that each a plot exists, and that its success would mean the perpetuation of the present regime, and they are exhorted to band themselves together to defeat it. One cannot help noticing a marked revival in the talk that the camarilla at Yildis desires to see Prince Burhaned din succeed his father and that it is prepared to resort to a coup defeat in order to change the order of succession. In diplomatic circles the whole story is regarded as an idle rumour; but it seems to be believed by most Turks and other natives, as well as by many of the foreign residents who are in closest touch with them. In some quarters it is even maintained that there is a connexion between this affair and the disgrace ot Kiamil Pasha.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Fakhry Pasha, Minister of Public Works, will leave for Upper Egypt on the 15th inst, on an inspection of irrigation. His Excellency will go as far as Assouan, whence he will return to Luxor and proceed to Kom-Ombo.
Saad Pasha Zaghloul arrived yesterday at Benha, where he visited the Government school.
Viscount and Viscountess Brackley,who have been staying at Bridgewater House, Sr. James's, for a few days, have left London for Egypt.

Viscount Brackley is heir to the earldom of Eilsemere, which peerage is a continuation of that of Bridgewater, the first Earl of which was created in 1617 and the 4 h was made a Duke. The 3rd and last Duke left a great part ot his immense fortune to his nephew, the Duke of Sutherland, with reversion to the latter's seoond son, Lord Francis Egerton, who obtained the Ellesmere title. The present heir was A.D C. to Major-General Knox in South Africa in 1900. In 1905 he married Violet, daughter of the Hon. F. W. Lambton, M.P., heir to the Durham earldum.

Among the passengers who arrived by the Schleswig yesterday were : Comte and Comtesse d'Albemarle, Comte Louis de Merode, Comte de Peurtales, Mr Heaton Armstrong, M P., Mr. C.F Bradley, Mune Loti, Baroness de Cumbo and daughters, Mr. Norman Orr-Ewing, Mr. D. Boubolis, Major Wynne, etc.

A very successful dance and "at home" was given last night by Colonel Cox and the officers of the 2 d Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers. In spite of the bad weather, large numbers of the best known members of the British and other colonies were present, and dancing was carried on to a late hour. The floor was excellent the refreshments highly appreciated, and the mingling of charming toilettes and military uniforms made the scene most picturesque. Among those present were Count Bernstoff, Count Kodesta de Koziebrodski, Major General Baden-Powell, Major General Bullock, and many others, whose names space will not allow ofour mentioning.

Lieutenant L. E G Oates, adjutant of the 6th (Inniskilling) Dragoons, who has then promoted to a captancy. is the son of the late Mr. W. E Oates (York Militia), and commenced his career in his father's old regiment. He was wounded whilst serving under Sir Charles Parsons in the South African war.

Lieutenant Boyd Alexander, Rifle Brigade, arrived at Plymouth on Saturday week on his return from his expedition across Central Africa. He had with him a collection of l,500 specimens of animals, birds, etc, shot during the tour, the number including a complete skin, said to be the only one in Europe, of the okapi. He has also brought home a rare chimpanzee, which goes to the Zoological Saoioty in London.
Mr. Perieles Zarifi, the well-known Greek banker of Constantinople, has arrived at Alexandria with his wife, and is staying with Mr. Rodocanachi.

Mr. Carl Meyer, chairman of the National Bank of Egypt and of De Beers Consolidated Mines, has left London for South Africa,where he will remain for about three months. He will return to England via Egypt.
The engagement is announced from Paris of M. Charles de Lesseps, son of Mame Victor de Lessens, nes Sinadino and grandson of Count Ferdinand de Lesseps, to Mile Edith Couturier.

The marriage of M. Richard M. Haddad to Alexandra, daughter of Mr and Mrs. Airut, will take place this afteronnn at 4.30 o'clock at the residence of the bride's parents, 4. Government Hospital-street.

The death has occurred at Haifa-under- Mount Carmel. Palestine, after a long illness, of the Rev. Bruce Dudley Ryder Baxter, M.A., formerly vicar of Helions Bumpstead, Essex, sometime English chaplain at Haifa.

div.head:
GERMAN ELECTION SENSATION.
ROLE OF NAVY LEAGUE.

div.p: A sensation has been created throughout Germany by the publication of purloined electoral correspondence showing that the Navy League, which was always understood to be non-political, had received 80,000 marks, and other support, from Price von Bolow and the Colonial Office for printing literature directed against the Centre. The Government is investigating the abstraction of the correspondence, and explains that the money was subscribed privately for the support of Government candidates but that official advice was asked regarding the distribution. (Reuter)

It is stated on good authority that President Roosevelt will to-day assure the Mayor of San Francisco that if he agress to end the agitation by abolishing the Oriental schools the President will use his influence to secure a treaty with Japan excluding Japanese coolies from landing. (Reuter)
Owing to pressure being brought to bear on the Government by Parliament, two Belgian. M. Nans, Minister of the Customs, and M. Priem, Chief Administrator, have been dismissed. (Reuter)

div.head:
WRECK OF M.M. STEAMER
THE CREW SAVED.

div.p: The Messageries Maritimes S.S. Laos, laden with rice from Indo-China, was totally wrecked on a rock, in a fog, near Saint Nazaire. The crew were saved. (Reuter)

At 3 o'clock this morning a tremendous explosion occured in the Chemical Research Department of Woolwich Arsenal at Plumstead Marshes. It destroyed the building, shook the whole town, and broke all the shop windows. The damage done amounts to about £22,000. (Reuter)
The notary's deed, declaring the entire subscription of the capital of the Moorish State Bank, was signed to-day by the founders at the Bank of France. (Havas)
On Saturday the police, who were forewarned, arrested six men of a gang waiting to attack a strongly escorted carriage conveying Custome receipts to the Bank. The rest escaped.
To-day a gang of 10 men in Moscow attacked a carriage conveying receipts of the Government Vodka depote. They secured 44,000 roubles and escaped.
A band similarly secured 16,000 roubles of Customs receipts at Batoum. (Reuter)

div.head: "FUTURE OF EGYPT."
div.p: MR. DICEY'S PROPOSALS.

In yesterday's issue we gave some details of the new work on Egypt by Mr. Edward Dicey. This gentleman proposes that Lord Cromer's system of government should be changed. The conclusion of "Egypt of the Future" gives the outline of Mr. Dicey's scheme. He thus sums up :—

My contention is that, putting aside our improvements in irrigation, whose utility the fellaheen can appreciate, the reforms we endeavour to introduce, and our interference with native customs, usages, laws, and habits give umbrage to the inhabitants of Egypt, and are also calculated to create an impression that they are directed against the authority of the Koran. If these reforms were carried out by native administrators speaking their own language, belonging to their own creed, and understanding their own prejudices, they would, I feel convinced, create far less discontent than they do at present. All change is distastefal to a conservative nation warmly attached to a non-progressive creed: and the unpopularity is all the stronger when the reforms are introduced by British officials often very imperfectly acquainted with their language, and so convinced of the superiority of British ideas as to deem their advantages too self evident to require explanation. I cannot but think that by this time—whatever may be the case with the British Agency- the great majority of our British officials must have come to the conclusion that any attempts to persuade the natives to accept British ideas respecting sanitation, law, justice, and administration are doomed to failure. This being so, the question is whether it is worth while to continue an experiment which has been proved impracticable.

If I am asked what I should propose as an alternative, I should recommend the system which has been adopted in the native States of India by England, in Tunis and Algeria by France, and in Bosnia and the Hezegoviua by Austria, and adopted with success. The fundamental principles of this system may be stated briefly as follows. Supreme authority should be vested in the hands of the representative of the Protecting Power, whether he may be called Resident, Governor, or Consul-General. Subject to this supreme authority, as little change as possible should be made in the internal administration of the protected State. The old laws, customs and usages should remain as they were before the Protectorate existed, and the old native administrators should as a rule be retained in the public service. These administrators should be clearly given to understand that they would be allowed a considerable latitude in the discharge of their funcitons, and that they would not be called to account if their administration should be considered somewhat differantly from the view entertained by the Protecting Power, but that if any gross scandal or abuse should occur during their administration they would be forthwith dismissed or, if necessary, severely punished by the representative of the Protectorate. To work out the details of such a system must be the work of the Resident, and this can only be done by the men on the spot. All I am concerned with is its broad principle.

In the provinces, all appointments up to the rank of Governor should be held by Egyptian subjects, who would be responsible for order and decent administration and would be liable to dismissal by the Consul-General in case any gross outrage or corruption were brought to the latter's knowledge. This, as I have already stated, is in substance, the scheme suggested by Lord Dufferin, and it is the one best fitted to render our Protectorate more congenial-or perhaps I should say less uncongenial-to the Egyptian public than that which has hitherto been adopted by the British Agency.

At the moment when I write two contingencies seem not unlikely to occur, either of which might bring about a crisis in Egyptian affairs. The first contingency is the possibility that the Great Powers may assent to Lord Cromer's demands for having a free hand in Egypt accorded to England not only by Frnace but by the other Great Powers in Europe. The second, and, to my mind, the far more probable contingency, is that the Powers may decline to accede to the demands I have recapitulated until the relaitons between England, as the Protecting Power, and Egpyt, as the Proctected State, have been discussed by an International Conference. In view of either of these contingencies, it is all important to c all the attention of England to the unsatisfactory character of our present unavowed Protectorate and to the failure of our existing policy of ruling Egypt by British officials in preference to administering Egyptian affairs with the cordial cooperation of the native element. This must be my excuse for the publication of The Egypt of the Future.

div.head: L'EGYPTE TELLE QU'ELLE EST.
div.p: L'OPINION D'UN INDIGENE.

L'lug. Moustapha Sabry vient de publier uu petit livre qu'il intitule "L'Egypte telle qu'elle est" (Gand 1906) Nous ne nous proposous pas de faire une analyse de ce livre ; nous avons toutefois pense que la conclusion qui est a la fin de ce volome (p. 199 a 202) pourrait peut- etre, au point de vue de la mentalite d'un Egyptien de nos jours, interesser quelques-uns de nos lecteurs ; c'est pourquoi nous publions ici cette conclusion :

En Egypte la pluie tombe a peine trois fois par au ; c'etait Son Altesse le Khedive qui faisait la pluie en distribuant l'eau du Nil dans les canaux d'irrigation ; il ne le pouvait qu'a force de bras : il fallait donc, dans l'interet'. general, que tous les bras fussent a ses ordres. Pour creuser les canaux et garder leurs digues il fallait des milliers de manaceuvres ; on prenait...les fellahs ; ils etaient requis, c'est a dire contraints de venir traveiller a la route, aux digues, a la batisse, s'il y avait lieu pendant des semaines, des mois entiers, meme des annees- et pour rien. Ce n'est pas tout: le pay en etait quelquefois force de se procurer de quoi vivre. Le fellah devait laisser son champ, ses travaux, sa masion. Il s'en allait que quefois bien loin; et en s'en allant il se detouruait pour regarder son sillion a demi trace, ou ses bles attendant la faucille. N'importe: il fallait marcher. Les femmes, les enfauts et les vieilards acheveraient comme ils pourraient le labour, la moisson commencee. Faire travailler les gens de force et sans les payer, c'est ce qu'on appelait une requisition: une fucan d'impos, plus lourde encore et plus penibe que toute autre.

Nos pauvres paysans quitterent douc leurs champs et vinrent travailler a la route, sous les ordres de contre-maitres Les uns creusaient la tranchee ; les autres dans la carriere voisiue, au flanc du coteau, arrachaieut la pierre eu gros blocs, d'autres coupaient des branches, abattaient des arbes, que d'autres encore portaient ou transaient; d'autres rangeaieut, tassaient, piolonnaient les blocs et faisaient la chuses. Qui les nourrissait pendant ce temps la C'etaient touj urs les parents qui fournissaient tobt. Et avec cela rudement traites, moins en ouvriers qu'en betes de aomme.

Le laboureur ne s'appartenait pas, il etait au gouvernement; il e'ait a un proprietaire. Il y avait un premier betail, le troapeau, et un deuxieme betail, le psysan. Aiusi la depopulation partout, point de vraie culture, un sillon de ests du laboureur.
La proprie e et la liberte seules font aimer la terre.
Nun. helas le pauvre paysan ne peut par, et surtout il ne sait pas se def ndre contre les atraques de son maitre ou de sou contre-maltre.

Le fellah est trop ignorant, le simple hommo, trop desarme; et puis, il faut le dire, on n tout fait pour lui o er l'envie de reclamer. Il est battu, maltraite jusqu'ace que vienne enfin le jour de la justice. Mais que cejour est loin encore

De malheureux psysans, desesperes, s'enfuysient dans les deserts et y menaient une vie de sauvages ou plutut de bares fauves; ou bien, se reunissaut par bandes, s'en allaient par les campagnes, pillant, massacrant, plus a craindre que des coupe.

L'homme aime, vraiment, la patrie parce qu'il y aime son champ. Qu'on possede un coin de torre ou la moitie d'une province, qu'en possede, tout est dit: c'est la le hic. Or quand l'aristocratie possede tout, le people ne possede rien et reste malheureux.

L'amelioration du paysan se fit lentement, graduellement. Maintenant, hiureusemeut pour lui, le fellah trouve le bien-entre de son etat individuel. Sa vie privee est moins triste qu'elle l'etait. Quoiqu'il conserve quelques habitudes rustiques, il me semble qu'il est plus intelligent et plus avance dans la civilisation que le paysan d'autrefois. Cependant chez les deux, la Foi, le devonement triompherent koraniquement dans leaurs actes. On les voyait se fatiguer et s'epuiser, inondes de transpiration, couverts de poussiere, mais toujours plus en clins a donner a manager aux pauvres.

Rien n'est agreable ni facile pour le fellah. A travers les maissons s'en vont, serpentaut les rues du village. Dea rues... plutot des voies de communication, pas pavees, tortueuses, mal alignees, larges ici, etroites la; les angles des maisoins avancent ou reculent. La chausssee inegale est defoncee par les piedsdes des bestiaux, et sale. C'est une pluie d'une courte duree qui la lave et la vent qui la balaie. On remarque souvent des ruelles si etroites que deux personnes n'y peuvent circuler l'une a coe de l'autre.

Maintenant, sous le regne auguste de Son Attesse Abbas Pacha Helmi II, notre Khedive actuel, les fellahs ont presque de l'aisance. Il y a encore des gens pauvres daus nos campagnes. Mais le nombre des malhaeureux va en diminuant, et diminuera encore plus vita, quand l'instruction et le progres seront artout.
Avec les grandes routes et les chemins de fer, les produits de la terre se vendent lien; et ceux qui ne sont pas encore dans l'aisance y arriveront, par le travail, l'instruction et l'economie.
En un mot, l'Egypte marche a de hautes destiuees particulierement sous son vice-roi actual, doux, noble, intelligent et loyal, qui est digne de donner a son pays cette derniere grandeur: la liberte.

Les fellahs, les maires, les chefs du gouvernement, sont de bons amis. L'accord suppose un developpement moral et intellectuel a peu pres egal chez tous. Plus les hommes sont pareils, plus les points de contact sont nombreux. Leur education prepare leur entente. Ils connaissent les memes angoisses et les memes incertitudes present sur eux ils se laissent gagner par les memes aspirations.

Nous, Egyptiens, nous avous, deplore avant peu encore les m seres de l'ignorance; que cela nons fasse estime a se valeur l'instruction d'on vient tout progres. E que l'exemple de quelques compatriotes qui, nes pour le devonement a la Patria, nous ont dote de otte conquete, nous encourage a marcher dans leur chemin, a nous instruire et a travailler vail lamment, pour menaror, autant qu'il est en nous et chache pur sa part, un Axenir de Paix et de Prosperite a l'Egypte, Notre Patrie et au Monde tout entier.

div.head: BALLADE OF PADGETT M.P.'s NEW WORK ON EGYPT.
div.p: No more of Thoth or Tarkosis.
The Hittite, or of Snefers
Who mined Moghara's turquoises
And battled with the wild Shasu:
Peace, dragoman! I cannot view
Antiquities without a smile
'Twas not for them I came to "do"
The land that worships Father Nile
Masrafs Mamurs, and Markezes,
Mean whites or blacks or browns who brew
"Booze," whose hearts are dark as is
The cuttle's ink, the Dinka's hue,
Mudirs and murders, Minbars, too,
And Ministers, my houre beguile;
Note book in hand I wander throngh
The land that worships Father Nile.
Though Millionaires or Marquises
Whose port is proud, whose blood is blue
Drag me to bridge their caroases
I thrust aside and cry—"go to
Spades, clobs, hearts, diamonds, "sans atout,"
The Smart Set's here, the gambler's wile,
I've but a fortnight left for you
Dear land that worships Father Nile.''
L'Envoi
My Lord, accept my tome, pursue The course I've hinted-(worth your while To read, mark, learn-and p'raus review THE LAND THAT WORSHIPS FATHER NILE'). GAEL.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: Yesterday was decidedlu unpleasant, especially in the afternoon, when about four o'clock the atmosphere became impregnanted with particles of fine dust and a high wind rose, making pedestrianists difficult. The wind continued during the night, moderate S.W. gales blowing, and the sea being rough. A change took place this morning and the prospects are for brighter conditions.

div.head: To Chilly Anaemcis.
div.p: Cold, Weak and Shivering.
A Victim's Sorrowful Plight.
Consumed with Excruciating Pain.
Wasting Away in a Rapid Decline.
Life is a Pleasure now.
A Splendid Cure found in DR. WILLIAMS' PINK PILLS.

'My feet and back were like stone, cold and numb, so anaemic did I become, and nothing seemed to impart any warmth to my body." This remark made by Mrs. Hassall, of 6, Upper Sidney-st., Bristol, is instructive, for eold in tha extremities, a poor eirculation, spinal shivers and a desire to sit huddled by the fire are all signs that the blood is weak and watery. In Mrs. Hassll's case these early symptoms were followed by serious developments. As she explained: —

"My back grew weak, and I could not lift anything. I could not breathe deeply without stabbing pains in my cbest, and gnawing pains under my shoulder blades made me languid and sick. Often I fainted, in spite of doctor's advice and that of a specialist I felt more wretched and weaker than ever. Then I attended hospital for months, and took many bottles of medicine, but I was overcome by nervous debility. A dreadful fear of death kept me from sleeping at night, and I would lie bathed in a cold perspiration. A backing cough began to trouble me, and I got so thin that every bone in my body could be counted. My chest was hollow, and the wheezing was awful every time I breathed. My body was shaky ; I trembled from head to feet, and I could not keep my head and hands still a moment. My husband had to lift my head and pour medicine into my mouth.
'One night my sufferings drove me delirious, and every time a spasm of pain shot through me my shrieks frightened my husband.

'Medicine was powerless' to help me, so I gave it up in despair. My stomach was by now quite incapable of digesting nourishment, however light. Doctors held out no hope of a recovery. Indeed, all ambition to live was gone and I wasted away in a rapid decline. Then neuralgia attaeked me, and every nerve in my head racked unmercifully. Burning paint shot through my back, and though my spine had been wrenched asunder. Friends sympathised, and my husband was worried out of his life with the fear of losing me.

"One day my niece came to me with news of a wonderful cure by Dr. Williams' Pink Pills for Pale People. Then my husband said, "We will soon test the truth. I will buy some of Dr. Williams' Pink Fills for you. I took them, and after the third or fourth box felt strong enough to do a little house-work. I persevered from the moment I found they were doing me good. I soon took solid food again without sickness, and my stomach grew brighter and a colour came into my cheeke. I lost all trace of weakness and dizziness, and my husband kept saying, 'This change is astonishing.' Dr. Williams' Pink Pills snatched me from the grave, and gave me back my old health and strength. My flesh is firm and solid again ; my cough has gone ; all trace of decline has vanished ; I am twice as active, and life is a pleasure now.

For languishing, lifeless, anemic girls and women there is no remedy equal to Dr. Williams' Pink Pills. They fill the veins with the rich good blood that restores strength, stimulates the nerves, and builds up the system. They have cured Anaemia, Indigestion, Eczema, Rheumatism, Sciatica, St. Vitus' Dance, Paralysis, Nervous Disorders and the many ailments of the weaker sex. Sold at shops, but avoid substitutes, and see that the full name is on every package, Dr. Williams' Pink Pills for Pale People.
Sold by all chemists and druggists at P.T. 18 the box and P.T. 70 for six boxs.

This Prospectus has been daily filed with the Registrar of JOINT STOCK COMPANIES OF LONDON.
The Subscription List will open and close on 14th February, 1907, at the Offices of the Cassa di Sconto e di Risparmio at Alexandria and Cario.
Industrial Building and Commercial COMPANY OF EGYPT, LTD.
(Incorporated under the Companies' Acts, 1862 to 1900
Divided into 499,375 Ordinary Shares of £1 each, and 12,500 Deferred Shares of 1/- each.

Of the above Ordinary Shares 299,375 are to be presently issued, and of these 83,000 are payable as part of the purchase money for the various properties acquired by the Company as mentioned herein, one-third of the balance or 72,125 are reserved for private subscription, and
SUBSCRIPTIONS ARE INVITED FROM THE PUBLIC AT PAR FOR 144,250 ORDINARY SHARES OF £1,

Payable as follows : 2/6d per share on application ; 7/6 per share on Allotment, and -10/- two months after allotment. Share Warrants to Bearer will be delivered free of stamp duty to Original Subscribers upon payment of their Shares in full, but no payment in anticipation will carry with it any right to dividend on the amount so paid in advance.
Directors.

Mr. S. V. Wood, 20, Bucklesbury, London, E.C.
Offices in Egypt.
4 Rue Salah el Din (Maison Degiarde), Alexandria.
PROSPECTUS

This Company has been formed for the purposes specified in the Memorandum of Association, and in particular to undertake contractcs for the construction of public buildings, private houses and other works, and to exploit the manafacturs of materials for construction and to acquire and carry on any business useful in this connection.
It is proposed also to purchase, improve, develop lease and otherwise deal with suburban and town properties when acquired, and to develop, building land by the erection of houses or otherwise.

A feature of the business of the Company will be the construction of buildings and houses on credit, the owner being allowed to pay the cost of construction by instalments with interest over an agreed number of years.

The present demand for honsee in Alexandria, Cairo and other towns in Egypt is beyond the capacity of existing constructors, and it is considered that there is ample scope for remunerative business for the Company in this connection.

The Company will also, as opportunity arises, acquire or finance or assist in financing sound industrial or commercial undertakings, more particularly those whose objects are useful to the general scheme of their undertaking.
The arrangements at present made on behalf of the proposed Company and the agreements entered into are as follows:

(1) An agreement dated 18th January 1907, made between the Cav. G. Mattioli of the one part and Mr. Emin Karam and the other Directors as trustees for the proposed Company of the other part. Under this agreement the Company will purchase as from the date of the ratification of this contract by the Company, as a going concern, the goodwill and business of architect and contractor of Mr. Mattioli, together with the bent fit of all contracts in course of being fulfilled. The price to be paid will be L E 3000, payable in cash and the Company will also pay Mr. Mattio in cash the value of the actual material and stock in hand on the day of the taking over, as disclosed by Mr Mattioli's books. Mr. Mattioli will also have allotted to him, 500 Deferred shares of the Company, for which he will pay in cash. The agreement also provide, for the appointment of Mr. Mattioli as General Manager (Directeur General) of the Company for 5 years at a salary of L.E. 2,000 a year, and a commission of 2 1/2 on the nett profits of the Company.

(2) As agreement dated 18th January 1907, between Mr. Salvatore Soilipoti of the one part and the Directors as trustees for the proposed Company of the other part. Under this agreement the Company will acquire from Mr. Soilipoti his mechanical saw works at Gabbari and the goodwill and business carried on by him as a going concern, as from the date of the ratifcation of this agreement by the Company. The price to be paid for the goodwill is fixed at £4,000, and the price of the freehold site and land at £ 4,571,056. The Company will also take over, at the price at which they figure in Mr. Scillipoti's books at the time of taking over, the buildings, material, and stock in hand. Of the total price Mr. Scilipoti will take £8,000 in fully paid up Ordinary Shares of the Company, and the balance in cash. This agreement also provides for the appointment of Mr. Scilipoti as Manager of the saw works and this branch of the Company's business for 5 years at a salary of L E. 480 per annum, and a comission of 8% on the profits of this branch.

(3) An agreement dated 18th January 1907 between Mr. Alfredo Campos of the one part and the Directors as trustees for the proposed Company of the other part. The Company will under this agreement purchase from Mr. Campos some 100,000 square pios of land in and about Ramleh at the price of about £54,000 of which £25,000 will be paid in fully paid Ordinary Shares of the Company, and the balance viz: about £19,000 in cash. The exact amount of purchase money will vary slightly according to the result of a definite measuring of the varions plots of land.

(4) An agreement dated the 30th December, 1906, between Mr. Emin Karem of the one part and Mr. Benvenuto Campos and the other Directors as trustees for the proposed Company of the other part, by which the Company will purchase from Mr. Karam 1000 feddans of land at Mariout, Behere; forming part of the demesne known as Hamman at the price of £25,060 payable in cash with reservation in favour of Mr.Karam of the exploitation of the bearing of gypsum thereon.

(5) An agreement dated the 18th January, 1907 between the Same parties as agreement No. 4. by which Mr. Karam renounces his rights to exploit the said bearing of gypenum, and concedes the same to the Company. The price to be paid for this renuciation and concession will be £65,000 plus 5,000 fully paid Deferred Shares Of the £65,000, Mr Karam will take £50,000 in fully paid Ordinary Shares ot the Company and the balances in cash.

(6) Agreement dated 18th January 1907, between Mr Emin Karam on the one part and Mr. Campo. and the other Directors as trustees for and on behalf of the Company of the other part, whereby, in consideration of the said Emin Karam underwriting the whole of the present issue to the public of Ordinary Shares in the Company. 7,000 of ehe Deferred Shares in the Compeny will be allotted to the said Emin Karam, with various persons. The 2,125 Shares reserved for private subscription will be subscribed and paid for in cash by an alloted to Mr. Emin Karim and the sub-underwrite any shares of this issue will receive as the nominte of Mr. Karam an allotment of Deferred Shares, for which he will pay. These are in addition contracts of an ordinary trade character which the Company will take over on requiring the properties and businesses before mentioned
The Directors who are the promoters, are interested in the promotion of the Company to the extent set out above and as shown in the contracts above referred to.
Except as mentioned above, no other sharer of this issue will be issued as fully or partly paid up otherwise than in cash.

The provisions of the Memorandum and Articles of Association with regard to the position of the Shareholders, division of profiss, creation of Reserve Fund and remuneration of the Directors are as follows :—

From or out of the profits of the Company which in respect of eacb year shall be available for dividends a sum equal to 10% of such profits shall be carried to a special Reserve Fund. The remaining 90%'of such profits shall be dealt with as follows:-

The holders of the Ordinary Shares are entitled (1) to a fixed preferential dividend at the rate of 6% per annum on the capital for the time being paid up or credited as being paid up thereon respectively, such dividend to be paid as regards each year, out of the profts of such year, and to be non-cumnlative, and to 50% of the surplus profits which in eacb year it shall from time to time be determined to distribute remaining after paying or providing for the above mentioned Reserve Fund and the payment of the said fixed dividend; (2) to priority as to return of capital and payment off of arrears of dividend whether declared or not ip to the commencement of the winding up.

The Deferred Shares confer on the holders thereof, rateably and in proportion to the number of Deferred Shares held by them respectively, the right to 40% of the surplus profits, which in respect of each year it shall be determined to distribute after paying or providing for the above mentioned Reserve Fund or the payment of the said fixed preferential dividend on the Ordinary Shares.

The Board of Directors will receive as remuneration for their servioes 10% of the surplus profits as above, after providing for the above mentioned Reserve and the payment of the said fixed preferential dividend. Such remuneration to be divided among the Directors in such proportions and manner as they themselves may determine and in default of suoh determination among them equally.
In addition to the aforesaid remuneration, each Director shall also receive such further sum (if any) as the Company in General Meeting may from time to time determine.

Any Director may be employed by or hold any office of profit under the Company, except that of Auditor of the Company, and may act either personally or as a member of the firm for, or render any professional service to the Company, and may receive remuneration from the Company for so doing in addition to any remuneration payable to him as a Director. If any Director, being willing, shall be called upon to perform extra services or to make any special exertions in going or residing abroad, or in negotiating or carrying into offset any contract or arrangement by the Company or otherwise for any of the purposes of the Company, or to act as trustee for the Company or its debenture holders, and shall do so, the Company may remunerate such Director either by a fixed sum of percentage of profits, or otherwise,as may be determined by the Directors, and each remuneration may be either in addition to or in substitution for, his remuneration above provided. If any Director shall be appointed to represent the Company as a Director of any subsidiary or other company in which the Company shall be interested, he shall, unless otberwise agreed, be entitled to retain the remuneration attaching to such Directorship for his own use.
No promotion money will be paid, except as aforesaid.

The preliminary expenses of and incidental to the formation of the Company down to and including allotment, includiog registration fees and stamp duty, legal expenses, the cost of advertising and issuing this prospectus, but excluding stamp duty on share warrants, will be paid by the Company, and are estimated at £50000.

Application for shares should be made to the accompanying form and forwarded with cheque for the amount payable on applioation to the Company's Bankers, Cassa di Sconto e di Risparmio, Alexandria and Cairo. If no allotment is made, the application money will be returned in full, and where the number of shares allotted is less than the number applied for, the surplus will be credited in rednetion of the amount payable on allotment and any excess will be returned to the applicant.
The Directors reserve to themselves discretion in the allotment of shares, but will endeavour, as far as possible to allot pro rata to the applications received.
Failure to pay an instalment on shares when due will render previous payments liable to be forfeited.

The minimum subscription upon which the Directors may proceed to allotment has been fixed by the Articles of Association at 10% if the shares offered. The whole of the present issue of shares has, however, as stated above, been underwritten.
A copy of the Memorandum of Association, which forms part of this Prospectus, is endorsed hereon.
A brockerage of 8d. per share will be paid to Bankers or Brokers on all shares applied for and allotted to the public on forms of application which bear their stamps.

The above mentioned contracts or copies of those documents toge her with the print of the Company's Memorandum and Article of Association may be inspected at the provisional offices of the Company at 4 Rue Salah El Dio , Maison Digiarde, Alexandria.
Copies of the Prospsotoe and appliovion fo-m i can be obtained at the same i ffi es and at the rffinee of the Ba- kers of -he Oompa >y at Cairo and Alexandria. Dated at Alexandria 81st January 1907.

div.head: Egyptian Salt & Soda Coy., Ltd.
div.p: The Directors of the Egyptian Salt & Soda Company, Ltd , have decided to issue at par 50,000 new ordinary shares of £1 (one ponud sterling) each to rank pari-passu with existing ordinary shares. The new shares are now offered by preference to Holders of the 450,000 existing ordinary shares, and will be allotted to applicants in the proportion of one new share for every complete nine old shares. Forms of application can be obtained from the Company's Bankers, the National Bank of Egypt, in Cairo, Alexandria or London.

Holders of share warrants to bearer wishing to exercise their right to subscribe must present their warrants to the Company's Bankers for verification and stamping from the 18th to 20th February 1907 together with application for the new shares and the sum of 10/- (ten shillings) per share applied for.The balance of 10/- (ten shillings) per share must be paid on or before 20th March 1907. Share Warrants to bearer will be issued to Allottees in respect of fully-paid sharesunpon application, and payment of stamp duties.
Registeted Share Holders should make application direct to the Secretaty at the Registered Office of the Company, 6 Old Jewry, London, E.C.

Applications for new shares must be received by the Company's Bankers or by the Company itself, as the case maybe, not later than 20th February 1907 after which date the Directors will allot any new shares not applied for, to such persons as they may deem fit.

Messieurs les actionnaires de la Societe Fonciere d'Egypte sont conviques en assemblee generale ordinaire et extraordinaire pour le Jeudi 28 fevrier 1907 a 3 heures de relevee, au Siege Social au Caire, Sharia Emad El Dine, immuable des bureaux Suares freres & Co, tant aux effets specifies a l'article 30 des Siatuts relativement aux assemblies ordinaires que pour deliberer au sujet d'une proposition du remboursement a faire sur les actions au moyen d'une partie des benefices et au sujet d'une proposition de reduction da Capital Social.

Tout actionnaire, proprietaire de 20 actions at, moins, qui voudra prendre part a la reunion devra faire le depot de ses actions avant le 24 fevrier courant: au Caire. au 3 Sege Soial; a Alexandria, chez Mess. R. Rolo figli & Co. on chez Mess. J. L. Menscee figlio & Co

div.head: Supplement Commercial et Financier DE "L'EGYPTIAN GAZETTE"
div.p: Le Supplement Commercial et Financier de "l'Egyptian Gazette" parait chaque Samedi a midi, de facon a pouvoir etre expedie par le paquebot autrichien. Il contient des revues completes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marche des valeurs: les dernieres statistiques jusqu'a la veil e de sa publication: des tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies des depeches officielles envoyees a la Liverpool Cotton Association, etc., etc.
L'abonnement pour une annee en Egypte coute 1 L.E. y compris les frais de poste; pou e tranger 10 P.T. de port en sus.

div.head: SPLENDID HOTELS
div.p: Les recettes du New Khedivial Hotel, depuis la clolture du dernier exercise en mai, a elevent a ce jour a plus de 16,000 L.E. et l'on a attend pour la fin de l'exercise au cours a un surplus de benefices de 7 a 8000 livres, en comparaison avec l'annee derniere.

Ces excellents resultate, dont nous n'avons tens aucen compte dans l'estimation de la valeur intrinseque des Splendid Hotels, font ressortir combien notre evaluation du titre a 6 livres etait moderee.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES

Le teux de l'escompte libre a Londres est toujours renseigne a 4 3/4 pour cent. Au Stock Exchange, avant-hier, le Consolide anglais est reste invarie a 87 1/8, ainsi que l'Unifiee a 102 3/4. La National Bank s'est mainteue a 28 5/8. L'Agricole a regagne 1/4 a 10, de meme que la Daira a 17 3/4. La Delta Light a avance de 1/8 a 12.
A Paris, le Crddit Foncier Egyptian a retrograde de 2 francs a 774. La Banque d'Athenes est restee invariee a 136.

Ici, le marche des valeurs a montre, ce matin, a l'ouverture, une certaine animation a laquelle n'ont pas tarde a succeder le calme et quelue peu de lourdeur. II y a lieu de mentionner particulierement un nonveau mouvement aur les Nungovivh et sur les fordateurs Estates, sinsi que sur les actions et fondateurs Express Nile.

Dans le compartiment des Barques, la National a molli a 9 5/16 3/8 L'Agricole s'est maintenue a 9 15/16-10. La Casaa di Sconto est restee a 277-278. La Barque d'Orient a progresse a 135. La part de fondateur Societe Generale Egyptienne s'est inscrite a 104.

Les Entreprises Immobilieres et Travaux ont cloture a L.E. 11 1/2 et leur part a P.E. 234. L'Epargne Immobiliere s'est tenue a 5/16; sa part a termine a 235. L'Express Nile a ete negocie aux environs de 6 1/2 pour finir a 6 3/8; sa part a avance a 345.
Les Jouissances Eaux du Caire se sont alourdies a 286. Les Ciments ont flechi a 60 et leur part a 12 13.

Dans le groupe del valeurs htotelieres, les Nungovich que nous avions laises samedi passe a 26 7/8-15/16, ont attaint jusqu'a 28 3/8 sur le bruit que la propriete du Savoy Hotel aurait ete, cette fois, bel et bien vendue, a L.E. 52 la metre, a l'Egyptian Estates Co., laquelle l'aurait retrocedes a une. Soceiete francasie. La titre a cloture a 27 15/16-28. Les Egyptian ont avance a 12 15/16 et les Upper Egypt a 4 7/8-15/16. Les Excelsior sont restes 4 11/16 et les National a 3 3/4-13/16.

Parmi les petites valears, la Delta Land a ete mieux tenue a 4 3/8-7/16. Les Estates ont progresse aux abords de 2 3/4 pour revenir a leur cours precedent de 2 5/8; leur part, tres demandee, a haussee jusqul a 25 5/8 pour cloture a 25 1/8, en avance de plus de deux livres sur le prix d'avant-hier. Les New Egyptian ont faibli a 30 sh. 1 1/2 et les Cotton Mills a 6 sh. 3. Les Constructions se sont raffermies a 1 3/8-7/16 et les Meimarachi a 0 5/8.
Suivant toutes probabilites, il y aurs cessation d'affaires a la Bourse du Caire demain, a l'occasion du Mardi-Gras.
En ce cas, le prochain No. de notre Circulaire ne puraltra que le mercredi 13 Fevrier courant.

On annonce d'Alexandria que les pourparlers relatifs a l'achat par la Ritz Hotels Co. du New Khedivial Hotel (Splendid Hotels of Egypt Co.) ont commence vendredi passe et promettraient d'aboutir dans un bref delai. L'echange se ferait sur la base de 5 livres environ par action des Splendid Hotels, soit en especes, soit en actions Ritz Hotels.
On sait que l'action Splendid Hotels a une valens nominale de L.E. 4 et qu'elle a ete emise avec 1/4 de livre de prime, soit 4 1/4. Le veleur nominale de l'action Ritz Hotels est de £1.
Des assembles extraordinaires des actionnaires des deux Societe seraient naturel smart convoques poor approuver et ratifier l'operation.

L'emission de 50,000 actions nouvelles de la Salt and Soda Co. Ltd, annoucee depuiquelque temps, sera ouverte le 18 Fevrier con rant pour etre close le surlendemain a la National Bank of Egypt, au Caire, a Alexandrie et a Londres. Ces actions soot offertes de preference au pair aux detenteurs des 450,000 actions deja existance dans la proportion de 1 action nouvelle pour 9 anciennes. Une somme de 10 shellings devre etre versee a la souscription ; le solde de 10 shellings sere exigible avant le 20 Mars prochain.

On announce de Londres le formation d'une Societe anonyms sours la denomination de "S and S. Sednaoui and Co. Ltd.," au capital de £215,000, en lOO actions de £2,150 ehaoune. L'objet de la Compagnie est d'acquerir et d contianer les affaires de la maison de commerce Selim et Simeon Sednaoui en Egypte et en France.

Apres un prelevement d'un premier dividende de 5% pour les actions, le surplus de benefices sera reparti comme suit: 10% a la reserve, 10% aux administrateurs, 5% a deseuvres de bienfaisance, 5% aux employes d la Societe et 70% comme dividends supple mentaire aux actionnaires.

div.head: KAISERLICH DEUTSCHES KONSULAT.
div.p: AUFGEBOT.

Es wird hiermit bekannt gemacht, dass der Bayerische Staatsangehorige ARTHUR GEORG EDUARD von Haas seines Standes Juspektor der Ottomanischen Bank in Konstantipen, geboren in Konstantinopel, 29 Jahre alt, wohnhaft in Konstantinopel, Sohn des im Alter von 48 Jahren in Konstantinopel verstorbenen Johannes Valentin von Haas, ehemaligen Direktors der Otoomanischen Bank in Konstantinopel, and der in Munchen wohnhafren Alice Maria gaborenen Black, 58 Jahre alt, ohne Beruf,

und die egyptische Staatsangehorige Franlein MARGUERITE ANNA DAHAN, geboren in Alexandrien veatorbenen Rentiers and dragomans des hollasdischen Konsulats in Alexandrien George Yakonb Dahan and der in Alexandrien wohn halften 44 Jahre alten Rosa geborenen Michalla ohne Beruf, beabsichtigen sich mit einander zu verehelichen und diese Ehe in Gang sheit des Reichsgesetzes vom 4 Mai 1870 vor dem unterzeichneten Bemen atzuschliessen.
Alexandria, den 8 February 1907. Der Kaiserliche Konsul.

div.head: Nile Cold Storage Company, Limited.
div.p: N0TICE IS HEREBY GIVEN that an Extraordinary General Meeting of the Nile Cold Storage Company, Limited, will be held at the Offices of the Cairo Water Company Sharia Boulac, Cairo, Egypt, on Wednesday the twenty seventh day of Febrnary 1907, at 5.30 o'clock in the afternoon, when the sub-joined Special Resolution will be proposed:

'THAT the Capital of the Company be "reduced from £50,000 to £10,000, in "manner following: - "By cancelling paid up Capital which "has been lost or is unrepresented by "available assets to the extent of four "shillings on each of the 49,750 Ordinary 'Shares, and to the extent of two and "three fifths pence (or some approximate sum) on each of the 5,000 Deferred "Shares, and accordingly reducing the "nominal amount of each of the said "Ordinary Shares to sixteen shillings and "reducing each of the said Deferred Shares "to nine and two fifths pence (or some "approximate sum) fully paid."

Holders of Share Warrants to Bearer who desire to be present personally or by proxy are required to deposit their Warrants at one of other of the following Banks, viz:—The Bank of Egypt, The National Bank of Egypt, The Anglo-Egyptian Bank, The Imperial Ottoman Bank, The Credit Lyonnais, or at the Offices of the Company in Cairo at least ten days before the Meeting, and most produce a receipt for the Warrants at the Meeting.
Dated at Cairo this thirty first day of January, 1907. By order of the Board, W.H. PERKINS, Secretary.

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list shewing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:—
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 14 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers of the P.& O., the Egyptian Mail S.S,. Co., North German Lloyd, Orient, and Messageries Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, Bibby and Henderson Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said can now be made without change in 4 ½ hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.

The quickest through Continental routes are by P.& O. Brindisi express from Port Said, by the Egyptian Mail S.S. Co., from Alexandria to Marseilles and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe. The Egyptian Mail S.S. Co., have also made arrangements whereby luggage can be collected and sent to any address.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis” to Brindisi. One of these leaves Port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.
